messages.message:
We have discovered one more high security vulnerability. This was published on October 29th and is specific to thrift 0.12.0 and lower versions. https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-0205

Investigations are underway on how to mitigate this vulnerability. (cc @will @dlluncor)
Can we bump the version on that library?
Yes. I am also checking whether thrift compiler needs to be upgraded
There does not seem to be a way out of this one. PY's latest thrift ver is 0.11.0 and NodeJS's latest ver is 0.12.0 :disappointed:
(it is beginning to seem that we will need to have some tough conversations with our customers)
I tried file service with PY 0.11.0 and dynamic proxy with 0.12.0. No luck.
I'll be away until evening -- @dlluncor let me know if you have any ideas. I am running out of them.
hey @Ashish — so would moving to 0.11.0 fix it for Python?
what issues are you seeing when you upgrade to 0.11.0 and 0.12.0 for dynamic-proxy?
The vulnerability does not go away. Our scanner still indicate that we have a high security vulnerability.

| hey @Ashish — so would moving to 0.11.0 fix it for Python?
No. It does not remove the security vuln.
```CVE-2019-0205           thrift-0.11.0                                           High              None                        https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-0205```
oh got it — then we’re kind of stuck no?
```CVE-2019-0205           thrift-0.12.0                                           High              None                        https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-0205 ```
yeah I think so
re-write all our services to grpc today? :slightly_smiling_face: jk
RPC here we come!
Well gRPC needs plenty of load testing. gRPC out of the box may not work well in a kubernetes environment that auto scales up or down. (The focus is on the word: `may`)
https://kubernetes.io/blog/2018/11/07/grpc-load-balancing-on-kubernetes-without-tears/
gotcha — the vulnerability seems pretty low though — since it’s just an inifite loop with a very specific type of data passed into it
looks like thriftpy2 might be an alternative here: https://github.com/Thriftpy/thriftpy2
Yeah we'll chat with customers. It will possibly cause a few back and forth with some customers specifically BAML and JPMC (cc @Matt and @mmark).
albeit not a quick alternative — but longer term perhaps we could try to use this library so that we don’t depend on what seems to be the no longer supported Thirft Python from FB
sounds good
I'm signing off until evening
